docs.lead_paragraph: Sheila Dean will not say, not out loud, why Thanksgiving is so special this year. She will hint at the reason, whisper about it. For Anthony Dean, the man she lives with and plans to marry and whose name she has already taken, there will be no Thanksgiving next year, the doctors say. Mr. Dean is dying of cancer. With luck, he will see Christmas, maybe his 57th birthday in January. Sitting in the half light of their downtown Brooklyn apartment, Sheila Dean silently mouthed the words, ''I don't know if he is going to live.''

headline.main: A Meal With Family Alleviates the Burden For a Dying Man

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign continues; work of Catholic Charities in providing Thanksgiving Day meals to needy discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NOW it was my turn. For shame's sake, if for no other reason, it was time to create my own home office. After all, I had spent the last two years immersing myself in other people's work spaces for a book on home offices -- only to find myself writing it in a crowded corner of my bedroom. Tired of seeing piles of photographs next to piles of socks, I couldn't cope with my own disorganization. I felt like Travis Bickle descending into madness in ''Taxi Driver'' -- the scene where he says to Betsy, the campaign worker, ''One of these days, I got to get organizized.'' I had seen dozens of ideal setups -- a limestone Tuscan-style tower in Texas, an indoor-outdoor office with a wisteria-covered pergola in Los Angeles, a diminutive outbuilding set on the edge of a pine-bordered marsh on Cape Cod.

headline.main: An Insider's Guide to the Homey Home Office

docs.abstract: Article by Donna Paul, author of The Home Office Book, on furnishing a home office in small space and on a small budget; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed taking a formal role in the Administration's welfare-reform strategy, fur flew. The right slammed the idea, publicly. ''We've finally got the chance to move people off welfare, and we really don't need the tender loving care of Hillary Clinton to mess it up,'' said Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin.

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Association of Retired Persons has said that it is in discussions about endorsing managed-care plans for its 30 million members with U.S. Healthcare, Kaiser Permanente and seven other health maintenance organizations in 18 markets across the nation, and that it hopes those plans will be available by mid-1997. The A.A.R.P. also said in the announcement on Monday that it was making progress in negotiations for expanded health insurance, including supplemental Medicare, managed-care and long-term-care coverage, for members aged 50 or older.

headline.main: A.A.R.P. in Health Plan Talks With Managed-Care Businesses

docs.lead_paragraph: Drunken driving deaths are up and the push for stricter laws is faltering, Mothers Against Drunk Driving said in a report today. The group said the number of alcohol-related traffic fatalities, which had been falling since 1986, rose last year, to 17,274 from 16,580. And it gave the states a grade of C for their efforts to reduce such fatalities, down from B-minus when the organization issued its last so-called report card, in 1993.

headline.main: Group Says Alcohol-Related Traffic Deaths Are Rising Again

docs.abstract: Mothers Against Drunk Driving reports drunken driving deaths have increased and that push for stricter laws is faltering; reports number of alcohol-related traffic fatalities, which had been falling since 1986, rose in 1995, to 17,724 from 16,580; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF I had been paying more attention, I might have noticed the plaque outside the room that the obstetrician was ushering us into: Patient Education. And had I noticed, I almost surely would have been alarmed. I was 20 weeks pregnant with my first child and had just had a ''routine'' ultrasound examination. What did I need to be educated about? But I did not notice, and I was not anxious or on guard. I had enjoyed the sonogram. Expectant parents do. It is a bonding opportunity. It is baby's first video. I had already had amniocentesis several weeks earlier, to check for chromosomal abnormalities associated with so-called elderly gravidas like my 38-year-old self.

headline.main: Ultrasound and Fury: One Mother's Ordeal

docs.abstract: Natalie Angier article questions routine use of ultrasound examination during pregnancy, noting possibility of false or misleading interpretations of scan; describes how ultrasound scan led her obstetrician to caution that her baby might be born with clubfoot, creating terrible anxiety for her and her husband; baby was born healthy and normal; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1877, a group of poor and angry farmers gathered in the hill country of Texas, vowing to fight the banks, railroads and other ''monied interests.'' It was the spark that set off the Populist movement, a network of cooperatives and political action that grew into one of the largest democratic insurgencies in the nation's history. Invoking that same spirit and directing their ire at modern forces like health-insurance companies and entertainment conglomerates, some 250 unabashedly left-leaning activists from 32 states met here in the hill country this weekend for the founding convention of what they pledged would be a populist alliance for the 21st century, ''a new national force to end the corporate rule of America.''

headline.main: Texas Meeting Seeks A Rebirth of Populism

docs.abstract: Some 250 left-leaning activists from 32 states meet, Hunt, Tex, to found national populist alliance; some 45 local 'alliances,' most of them urban-based, have quietly sprouted around nation in last 15 months; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After signing up large numbers of New York doctors and establishing a seemingly unshakable position here, health maintenance organizations are radically changing the way they pay physicians and have begun to reduce reimbursements. Patients who see the same doctor in the same office are generally not aware that a change has occurred. But while the health maintenance organizations assert that new types of payments help control medical costs, the region's doctors, and medical experts, are warning that the quality of care will suffer and that in some cases, it already has.

headline.main: Reduced H.M.O. Fees Cause Concern About Patient Care

docs.abstract: Health maintenance organizations, after signing up large numbers of New York area doctors and establishing seemingly unshakable position here, are cutting physician reimbursements; doctors and medical experts warn of threat to quality of care; plans that pay old-style fees for office visits have cut rates, sometimes on monthly basis; many of large plans have stopped paying doctors per visit and instead give them small fixed fee for office care for each enrolled patient; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the White House and Congress prepare to attack the big issues that could shape the economic landscape for years to come, Washington is bathed in something of a rosy glow. Balancing the budget? Bipartisan cooperation should yield a happier outcome this time around.

headline.main: An Economy of Happily Ever After?

docs.abstract: As Washington bathes in post-election presumption that country need not worry about serious business downturn any time soon, some economists are suspicious of attitude that we have tamed once-ominous business cycle and that inflation is dead; while there are solid reasons for optimism, both political parties claim to have learned painful lessons of fiscal recklessness; current economic expansion, five years and eight months old, is already third-longest of century; should it last until, 2002, target date agreed on by both parties for eliminating deficit, it would be longest on record; recession on the other hand would wreak havoc on the effort to balance the budget; chart on performance of stock market for 12 trading days following election eve since 1900 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Against Wealth HMOs and the Breakdown of Medical Trust. By George Anders. 299 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95. The spread of ''managed care'' has been so rapid and unanticipated that a backlash was inevitable. ''Health Against Wealth,'' by George Anders, an able reporter for The Wall Street Journal, is part of that backlash. Mr. Anders argues that cost-driven managed care companies are systematically degrading the quality of medicine. Managed care generally works for people who need only routine treatments or checkups, Mr. Anders contends, but for the seriously ill it often provides too little too late. The reason is simple. Serious illnesses consume most of the health-care dollar and, therefore, inspire managed- care companies to impose daunting obstacles to aggressive treatment. The restrictions may be good for profits, he warns, but they're bad for patients.
docs.abstract: Robert J Samuelson reviews book Health Against Wealth: HMOs and the Breakdown of Medical Trust by George Anders; drawing (M)
